articles.headline: For Europe’s Jews, a World of Fear
articles.snippet: The Oct. 7 Hamas assault on Israel and a surge in acts of antisemitism have awakened a repressed horror in Jewish populations across the continent.
articles.abstract: The Oct. 7 Hamas assault on Israel and a surge in acts of antisemitism have awakened a repressed horror in Jewish populations across the continent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Perhaps not since the Holocaust, which saw the annihilation of about two-thirds of Europe’s Jewish community, have the Jews of Europe lived in an atmosphere of fear so acute that it feels like a fundamental shift in the terms of their existence.

articles.headline: They Propelled China’s Rise. Now They Have Nothing to Fall Back On.
articles.snippet: Migrant workers, who moved from China’s villages to its big cities, were a secret weapon building the economy. Now many see few options.
articles.abstract: Migrant workers, who moved from China’s villages to its big cities, were a secret weapon building the economy. Now many see few options.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Zhang left his village in northeastern China a decade ago to work as a welder in a big city, jobs were plentiful. He earned about $50 a day and managed to save most of it.

articles.headline: Drought Saps the Panama Canal, Disrupting Global Trade
articles.snippet: The number of ships that can travel through the vital route has fallen sharply this year because of a lack of water for the locks, raising costs and slowing deliveries.
articles.abstract: The number of ships that can travel through the vital route has fallen sharply this year because of a lack of water for the locks, raising costs and slowing deliveries.
articles.lead_paragraph: For over a century, the Panama Canal has provided a convenient way for ships to move between the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans, helping to speed up international trade.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Nathalia Angarita

articles.headline: If Trump Wins, His Allies Want Lawyers Who Will Bless a More Radical Agenda
articles.snippet: Politically appointed lawyers sometimes frustrated Donald J. Trump’s ambitions. His allies are planning to install more aggressive legal gatekeepers if he regains the White House.
articles.abstract: Politically appointed lawyers sometimes frustrated Donald J. Trump’s ambitions. His allies are planning to install more aggressive legal gatekeepers if he regains the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: Close allies of Donald J. Trump are preparing to populate a new administration with a more aggressive breed of right-wing lawyer, dispensing with traditional conservatives who they believe stymied his agenda in his first term.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Swan, Charlie Savage and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Offshore Wind Firm Cancels N.J. Projects, as Industry’s Prospects Dim
articles.snippet: Denmark’s Orsted said it would be forced to write off as much as $5.6 billion as wind developers in the U.S. faced wrenching financing costs.
articles.abstract: Denmark’s Orsted said it would be forced to write off as much as $5.6 billion as wind developers in the U.S. faced wrenching financing costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Plans to build two wind farms off the coast of New Jersey were scrapped, the company behind them said on Wednesday, a blow to the state’s efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions and the latest shakeout in the U.S. wind industry.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Tracey Tully

articles.headline: Those Promotions Promising a ‘Free’ iPhone? It Isn’t Free.
articles.snippet: The so-called iPhone giveaways marketed by Verizon, T-Mobile and AT&T can make customers spend more on perks they don’t need.
articles.abstract: The so-called iPhone giveaways marketed by Verizon, T-Mobile and AT&T can make customers spend more on perks they don’t need.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s no such thing as a free iPhone.
